addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

5
th
August
1589
M
r
Bodleys proposition unto the States for the acceptacion of 1200 foote in Lieu of the 600 horse w
th
drawen from thence

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. uppon
e receat of yo
r
letter of
e 28 of July, whiche I receaved
by this post
e 8 of this p
nt
, I have bin in-
stant againe w
t
e
Generall states
, for a spedy
answear to her
Ma
tie
about
e mater of com-
mission,
at should be sent to their Deputies:
wheruppon
ei have promised nowe, to take some
present resoluc
o
n, whiche as farre as I perceave,
whilbe ready to be sent w
t
in three or fower daies
What is like to be resolved, I can not learne by
any meanes. For nothing is imparted with
e
Councell of state
, but all is kept w
t
suche a
jalouse secrecie, as if
ei feared to be wrought
by
e Councell, to hold better correspondence be-
tweene her Ma
tie
and
e contrey. Wherein, if
that be their meaning, they shall not finde them-
selves deceaved. For divers lately of
e Councell,
not w
t
me only, and in privat c
o
ference, but truly
publickly, and more then ever before, have complai-
ned very bitterly against
Barnevelts
courses.
And still
ei tell me privatly, that for feare of
perturbing
e state, they must forbeare to oppose
themselves directly against him, as also for
at
w
ch
yo
r
H. doth signifie, Because they see him
in a course, to runne himself out of breath.
The 5 of this moneth, I receaved one
from yo
r
H. w
t
charge to deale w
t
e states,
about
e acceptation of
e 1200 footmen, for 600
horse, wherein I moved them
e same day, and
since receaved suche answear, as I send yo
r
H.
herein, w
t
mine owne proposition.
fol.26v
That whiche I writte in my last, of
e enterprise
at
Nieumeghen,
had that successe whiche I signi-
fied. Only more we understand, that
e townes-
men since have fished for
Schincke,
and founde
him in his armo
r
: and since have cutte him in
q
a
rters, and sette him on their gates. Whiche
extraordinarie inhumanitie doth so exasperat
e states, as they will publishe an Edict uppon
it, that no quarter shalbe kept w
t
Nieumeghen.
Count Maurice
hath found
e meanes
by night, to convey three companies more into
Huesden,
every souldier carieng w
t
him a qu
a
tity
of powder. Whiche is thought in respect of the
want
ei had w
t
in, and
e danger of
e attempt,
a great peece of service.
My L.
Treasuro
rs
good opinion and report of my services,
whiche I knowe yo
r
H. doth confirme, as occa-
sions are presented, are suche encouragments
unto me, as if I knewe by w
at
meanes, I would
shewe my self more worthy of yo
r
honorable fa-
vo
rs
. But w
at
I want in abilitie, I hope to
make up in diligence, whiche I doe assure yo
r
H., to effect any good, must be more then ordi-
nary, and more then many will imagine, that
are not heere in place, to see
e daily thwartes
at are offered, and their broken proceedinges.
I am glad to knowe by yo
r
H. that my often
writing to my Lorde, wilbe well accepted. It
is
e last point of
at service, whiche I would
willingly shewe unto his L Whiche I have pur-
posely forborne, lest writing to yo
r
H. whiche,
if there were any mater, was also written to
fol.27r
my L. I mght seeme to be more troblesome,
then my buisnes did require.
And thus I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage. Au
g
9
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
